February 3, 1991: Fiction
COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds
hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan.
THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British
intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy.
THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) Europe in the Ice
Age.
THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of
President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert.
BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of
Marine corpsmen.
VITAL SIGNS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $21.95.) A physician's quest for fertility
brings her horrifying adventures in America, Australia and China.
DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and
romantic life of a California woman who becomes a photographer.
CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age
of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia.
JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician uses
genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park.
THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a
professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man.
POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British
academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets.
FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four tales about late-
night terror.
MIDDLE PASSAGE, by Charles Johnson. (Atheneum, $17.95.) A newly liberated
slave learns about himself and the world during a voyage to Africa in the early
19th century.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to
America.
THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An
February 3, 1991
Non-Fiction
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has
played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present.
A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the
itinerant television newscaster.
THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf,
$50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures.
BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The
autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and
football for the Los Angeles Raiders.
THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former
Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during
the past 15 years.
MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of
the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House.
YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The
different languages men and women speak.
THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton
Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish
and Muslim children.
POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently
occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives.
PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his
father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor.
GOD, COUNTRY, NOTRE DAME, by Theodore M. Hesburgh with Jerry Reedy.
(Doubleday, $21.95.) The autobiography of the theologian and former president of
the University of Notre Dame.
DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's
memoir of a period of severe depression.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the inspirational essay, with
new commentary.
